postcontent:
The VZ.2008 is Century Arms' version of the Czech VZ.58 rifle. The Czechs have a long and glorious history of small arms manufacture, and under Soviet rule, they were the one Russian satellite country given permission to create alternatives to Russian weapons. The VZ.58 was an alternative to the AK-47. It fires the same round and looks cosmetically similar, but the mechanism and magazines are different. Function is very similar, the most noteworthy difference being that the bolt locks open on empty magazine.

This is one of the Century Arms rebuilt kit rifles. The receiver and barrel are U.S.-made. The furniture and most other parts are Czech. Furniture is the Czech "wood-impregnated" plastic - it has an interesting old-fashioned wooden look but is supposed to be more weather-resistant. The gun is in great shape with under 300 rounds through it. I polished the feed ramp.

It is very handy (the only gun I own that I would compare favorably with an M1 Carbine or Winchester 1894 for overall handiness), and the folding metal stock allows it to be very compact - I think it would fit in a backpack, though I haven't actually tried.

It comes with five magazines, which hold 30 rounds each. It fires the same 7.62x39 round as the SKS and AK-47. I can include some ammunition as a sweetener.

In full disclosure: Century Arms is not a particularly respected manufacturer. I love this rifle, but while it worked 100% for me with FMJ Tula rounds, I got some jams with HP Wolf rounds. Your mileage may vary. In my case, I was thinking of it as a potential home defense weapon, and if I can't use HP rounds in it, I'm not as interested. If you approach it as a range toy, it's a thing of beauty.

I am realistic about its value.

Includes:
The VZ.2008
Cardboard box
Leather magazine pouch and five magazines
Depending on the deal, I can include some Tula ammunition
